facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 821 and 822 of 1971 were filed by certificates from the judgment and orders dated July 14 and August 22, 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Petitions Nos. 957 and 3784 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 821 and 822 of 1971. Appeals by certificates from the judgment and orders dated July 14, and August 22, 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Petitions Nos. 957 and 3784 of 1970.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1625 and 2008 of 1971 were filed by certificates from the judgments and orders dated July 14, 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 953 and 928 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1625 and 2008 of 1971. Appeals by certificates from the judgments and orders dated July 14, 1970 of the Allahabad High Court at Allahabad in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 953 and 928 of 1970.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the, Court was delivered by Hegde, J. These are appeals by certificate. They raise companymon questions of law for decision, and they are directed against a companymon judgment of the Allahabad High Court.

facts.text: The appellants are dealers in foodgrains including cereals and pulses especially split or processed foodgrains and dal.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case lie within a narrow companypass. The appellants are dealers in foodgrains including cereals and pulses especially split or processed foodgrains and dal. The dispute in this case centers round the question whether the Government is companypetent to levy sales-tax on the purchases made by the appellants of split processed foodgrains and dal under the provisions of the United Provinces Sales Tax Act, 1948 as amended by the Uttar Pradesh Sales Tax Act  Amendment and Validation  Act, 1970  which will hereinafter be referred to as the Act .

facts.text: The dispute centers on whether the Government is competent to levy sales-tax on purchases made by the appellants of split processed foodgrains and dal under the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 as amended by the U.P. Sales Tax (Amendment and Validation) Act, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute in this case centers round the question whether the Government is companypetent to levy sales-tax on the purchases made by the appellants of split processed foodgrains and dal under the provisions of the United Provinces Sales Tax Act, 1948 as amended by the Uttar Pradesh Sales Tax Act  Amendment and Validation  Act, 1970  which will hereinafter be referred to as the Act . Under the Sales Tax Act as it originally stood which will -hereinafter be referred to as the principal Act , the purchases of split or processed foodgrains and dal by dealers were sought, to be brought to tax under s. 3-D of the principal Act read with the numberification issued.

facts.text: Validity of the levy was challenged by Tilock Chand Prasan Kumar, the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 1625 of 1971, in respect of the assessment made on him for the assessment year 1966-67 by assessment order dated June 30, 1968 by means of a writ petition under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the levy was challenged by Tilock Chand Prasan Kumar, the appellant in Civil Appeal NO. 1625 of 1971 in respect of the assessment made on him for the assessment year 1966-67 by assessment order dated June 30, 1968 by means of a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court struck down the levy holding that the dal purchased by the petitioner could not be said to be a commodity essentially different from the arhar dal purchased by the dal mills and accordingly the purchases effected by the petitioner could not be regarded as the first purchases. Reported in 25 T.C. p. 118.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Allahabad struck down the levy holding that the dal purchased by the petitioner before it companyld number be said to be a companymodity essentially different from the arhar dal purchased by the dal mills and accordingly the purchases effected by the petitioner companyld number be regarded as the first purchases. This decision is reported in 25, T.C. p. 118.

facts.text: Governor of U.P. issued Uttar Pradesh Sales Tax Amendment and Validation Ordinance, 1970 (U.P. Ordinance No. 2 of 1970) adding inter alia Explanation II to s. 3-D as well as s. 7 to the principal Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Governor of U.P. issued an ordinance known as Uttar Pradesh Sales Tax  Amendment and Validation  Ordinance, 1970  U.P. Ordinance No. 2 of 1970  adding inter alia Explanation 11 to s. 3-D as well as s. 7 to the principal Act. This ordinance was later on enacted as an Act to which we have already made reference.

facts.text: The Ordinance was later enacted as the Uttar Pradesh Sales Tax (Amendment and Validation) Act, 1970. Provisions identical.

anchor.surface_text: This ordinance was later on enacted as an Act to which we have already made reference. The provisions of the Amending Act are identical with the provisions in the Ordinance.

facts.text: The Amending Act came into force during the pendency of the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Though at the time of the institution of the writ petitions from which these appeals arise, the Ordinance had number yet been made into the Act, the Amending Act came into force during the pendency of the writ petitions.

facts.text: Notification issued under s. 3-D of the principal Act on October 1, 1964 (Notification No. S.T. 7122/X) provided that with effect from October 1, 1964, turnover of purchases of foodgrains liable to tax at 1.5 paise per rupee on first purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification issued under s. 3-D of the principal Act on October 1, 1964  Notification No. S. T. 7122/X  provided that with effect from October 1, 1964, the turnover of purchases in respect of goods mentioned therein shall be liable to tax under s. 3-D at the rate mentioned Foodgrains 1.5 paise per rupee on first purchase

facts.text: Explanation II added to s. 3-D deems split or processed foodgrains, such as dal, to be different from unsplit or unprocessed foodgrains for tax purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Under the. Amending Act one more Explanation viz., Explanation 11 was added to s. 3-D. For the purposes of this sub-section, split or processed foodgrains, such as in the form of dal shall be deemed to be different from unsplit or unprocessed foodgrains, and accordingly, numberhing in this sub-section shall be companystrued to prevent the imposition, levy or companylection of the tax in respect of the first purchases of split or processed foodgrains merely because. tax had been im- posed levied or companylected earlier in respect of the first purchases of those foodgrains in their unsplit or unprocessed form.

facts.text: Section 7 added as validating provision to the principal Act deeming notifications under s.3-D valid retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: The Amending Act also added a validating provision to the principal Act viz. s. 7. That section reads Notwithstanding any judgment, decree or order of any companyrt or tribunal to the companytrary, every numberification issued or purporting to have been issued under Section 3-A or Section 3-D of the principal Act before the company- mencement of this Act shall be deemed to have been issued under that section as amended by this Act and shall be so interpreted and be deemed to be and always to have been as valid as if the provisions of this Act were in force at all material times and accordingly anything done or any action taken  including any order made, proceeding taken, jurisdiction exercised, assessment made, or tax levied, companylected or paid purporting to have been done or taken in pursuance of any such numberification  shall be deemed to be, and always to have been, validly and lawfully done or taken.

facts.text: Appellants challenged the validity of Explanation II to s. 3-D and s. 7 before Allahabad High Court in writ petitions under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants challenged the validity of Explanation 11 of S. 3-D as well as s. 7 introduced by the Amending Act before the High Court of Allahabad in petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court rejected the contentions and dismissed the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected these companytentions and dismissed the writ petitions. Thereafter these appeals have been brought after obtaining certificates from the High Court.

facts.text: Appeals brought after obtaining certificates from the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter these appeals have been brought after obtaining certificates from the High Court.

facts.text: Assessment order dated June 30, 1968 for Tilock Chand Prasan Kumar for assessment year 1966-67.

anchor.surface_text: by assessment order dated June 30, 1968 by means of a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The High Court of Allahabad struck down the levy holding that the dal purchased by the petitioner before it companyld number be said to be a companymodity essentially different from the arhar dal purchased by the dal mills and accordingly the purchases effected by the petitioner companyld number be regarded as the first purchases.

facts.text: Authorities sought to tax first purchases of processed or split foodgrains including dal as separate item under principal Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of s. 3-D read with the numberification, as mentioned earlier, the authorities under the Act sought to bring to tax under the principal Act the first purchases of processed or split foodgrains including dal on the ground that they companystituted a separate item of foodgrains quite independent of the unprocessed or unsplit foodgains.

facts.text: High Court negatived the view that processed or split foodgrains constituted separate item.

anchor.surface_text: This view, as seen above, was negatived by the High Court.

facts.text: Dealers have started applying for refund of tax already collected.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, the dealers have started applying for the refund of tax already companylected on these companymodities. Ibis will have serious repercussions on the States revenue.

No fresh notification needed; existing notification covers split/processed via Explanation II and s. 7

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the legislature cannot delegate its legislative functions to any other body-. But subject to, that qualification, it is permissible for the legislature to delegate the power to select the persons on whom the tax is to be levied or the goods

holdings.text: The legislature has power under Entry 54 List II to impose tax retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that subject to constitutional restrictions a power to legislate includes a power to legislate prospectively as well as retrospectively. In this regard legislative power to impose tax also includes within itself the power to tax retrospectively--see The Union of India v. Madan Gopal Kabra 1  M. P. Sundararamier Co. v. The State of Andhra Pradesh and Anr.  2  J. K. Jute Mills Co. Ltd. v. The State of Uttar Pradesh and Anr.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative power inherently includes prospective and retrospective operation; supported by multiple Supreme Court precedents like Madan Gopal Kabra.

holdings.text: Legislature competent to treat processed or split pulses as separate from unsplit or unprocessed pulses for single-point taxation under s. 3-D.

anchor.surface_text: Legislature was not incompetent to separate the processed or split pulses from the unsplit or unprocessed pulses and treat the two as separate and independent goods. In Jagannath and Ors. v. Union of India, 1  question arose for decision whether it was open to the legislature to impose separate excise duty on tobacco leaf as well as on broken leaf of tobacco.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature can define goods for tax; analogous to Jagannath case on tobacco leaf separation.

holdings.text: Amending Act does not usurp judicial power but validly changes law retrospectively to remove basis of prior High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: there is no justification for the contention that the legislature has usurped any judicial power. The legislature has not purported either directly or by necessary implication to overrule the decisions of the Allahabad High. Court in Tilok Chand Prasan Kumars case  supra . On the other hand it. has accepted that decision as correct but has sought to remove the basis of that decision by retrospectively changing the law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between overruling judgment and changing underlying law; legislature within competence.

holdings.text: Classification distinguishing processed/split pulses from unprocessed/unsplit pulses is reasonable and not violative of Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: The classification between the processed or split pulses and un- processed or unsplit pulses is a reasonable classification. It is based on the use to which those goods can, be put. Hence, in our opinion, the impugned classification is not violative of. Art. 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on capability of use; wide latitude in tax classification per precedents like Jagannath and Khandige Sham Bhat.

holdings.text: Explanation II to s. 3-D widens scope of s. 3-D by deeming split/processed foodgrains different from unsplit/unprocessed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal construction and legislative intent clear; explanations can expand scope per precedents like Bihta Cooperative.

holdings.text: No fresh notification required; existing notification under s. 3-D deemed to cover split/processed foodgrains via Explanation II and validated by s. 7.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction with s. 3-D, Explanation II, and s. 7 validation; avoids rendering s. 7 otiose.

holdings.text: Retrospective levy under the Act not violative of Art. 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: A feeble attempt was made to show that the retrospective levy made under the Act is violative of Art. 19  1   f  and But we see no substance in that contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No substance as levy within legislative competence; ability to pass on tax irrelevant to validity.

holdings.text: Delegation of power to Government under s. 3-D to notify goods for single-point tax is not excessive.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the legislature cannot delegate its legislative functions to any other body-. But subject to, that qualification, it is permissible for the legislature to delegate the power to select the persons on whom the tax is to be levied or the goods or the transactions on which the tax is to be lievied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permissible given complexity of economic/administrative factors; legislature sets framework in s. 3.

holdings.text: Government competent to levy sales-tax on first purchases of split/processed foodgrains and dal under amended s. 3-D and s. 7.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute in this case centers round the question whether the Government is competent to levy sales-tax on the purchases made by the appellants of split processed foodgrains and dal under the provisions of the United Provinces Sales Tax Act, 1948 as amended by the Uttar Pradesh Sales Tax Act  Amendment and Validation  Act, 1970  which will hereinafter be referred to as the Act .

holdings.reasoning_summary: All petitioner challenges rejected; amendments valid and effective retrospectively.

holdings.text: High Court correctly dismissed writ petitions upholding validity of Explanation II to s. 3-D and s. 7.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected these contentions and dismissed the writ petitions. Thereafter these appeals have been brought after obtaining certificates from the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation of lower court on all grounds after detailed analysis.

anchor.surface_text: This decision is reported in 25, T.C. p. 118. Thereafter the Governor of U.P. issued an ordinance known as Uttar Pradesh Sales Tax Amendment and Validation Ordinance, 1970 (U.P. Ordinance No. 2 of 1970) adding inter alia Explanation II to s. 3-D as well as s. 7 to the principal Act.

precedents.case_name: JK Jute Mills Co Ltd v State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: legislative power to impose tax includes power to tax retrospectively

precedents.citation: Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel and Co. v. The Union of India and Anr.

anchor.surface_text: Uttar Pradesh and Anr. Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel and Co. v. The Union of India and Anr. 4 Sri Ramkrishna Ors. v. The State of Bihar. 5 In the last mentioned case it was specifically decided that where the legislature can make a valid law,

precedents.case_name: Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel & Co v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: legislative power to impose tax includes power to tax retrospectively

precedents.citation: Sri Ramkrishna Ors. v. The State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: Union of India and Anr. 4 Sri Ramkrishna Ors. v. The State of Bihar. 5 In the last mentioned case it was specifically decided that where the legislature can make a valid law, it can provide not only for the prospective operation of the material provisions of the said law but it can also provide for the retrospective operation of the said provisions.

precedents.case_name: Sri Ramkrishna v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: legislature can provide for retrospective operation of provisions where it can make valid law

precedents.citation: Jagannath and Ors. v. Union of India

anchor.surface_text: goods. In Jagannath and Ors. v. Union of India, 1 question arose for decision whether it was open to the legislature to impose separate excise duty on tobacco leaf as well as on broken leaf of tobacco. This Court overruled the contention that such a levy was invalid.

precedents.cited_proposition: legislature can separate tobacco leaf and broken leaf for separate excise duty
precedents.cited_holding: open for legislature to separate the two items

anchor.surface_text: In Jagannaths case supra , this Court ruled that there was no unconstitutional discrimination in the imposition of the excise duty on tobacco in the broken leaf form. Therein it was observed that tobacco in the, broken leaf form was capable of being used in the manufacture of bidis while tobacco in the whole leaf form could not be so used economically the two forms of tobacco were different by the test of capability of user the tariff is not based either wholly or even primarily by reference to the

precedents.cited_proposition: no unconstitutional discrimination in separate levy on broken leaf tobacco; reasonable classification based on use

precedents.citation: Khandige Sham Bhat and Ors. v. The Agricultural Income Tax Officer

anchor.surface_text: In Khandige Sham Bhat and Ors. v. The Agricultural Income Tax Officer, 1 this Court laid down the tests to find out whether there are discriminatory provisions in a taxing statute. Therein this Court observed that in order to judge whether a law was discriminatory what had primarily to be looked into was not its phraseology but its real effect.

precedents.case_name: Khandige Sham Bhat v Agricultural Income Tax Officer
precedents.cited_proposition: tests for discriminatory provisions in taxing statutes: look to real effect not phraseology; wide discretion in classification

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay, City. Bombay v. Bipinchandra Maganlal Co. Ltd., Bombay

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay, City. Bombay v. Bipinchandra Maganlal Co. Ltd., Bombay, 1 this Court held that by the fiction in S. 10(2)(vii) second proviso read with S. 2(6C) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 what is really not income is, for the purpose of computation of assessable income, made, taxable income.

precedents.case_name: CIT Bombay v Bipinchandra Maganlal & Co
precedents.cited_proposition: provision called proviso can be separate provision altering main section
precedents.cited_holding: fiction in proviso made non-income taxable

precedents.citation: State of Rajasthan v. Leela Jain

anchor.surface_text: In State of Rajasthan v. Leela Jain 2 this Court observed The primary purpose of the proviso not under consideration is, it is apparent, to provide a substitute or an alternative remedy to that which is prohibited by the main part of S. 4(1).

precedents.case_name: State of Rajasthan v Leela Jain
precedents.cited_proposition: proviso can provide alternative remedy, covering wider field than main part
precedents.cited_holding: proviso not carving out but independent provision

precedents.citation: Bihta Co-operative Development Cane Marketing Union Ltd. and Anr. v. Bank of Bihar and Ors.

anchor.surface_text: In Bihta Co-operative Development Cane Marketing Union Ltd. and Anr. v. Bank of Bihar and Ors. 3 this Court was called upon to consider the Explanation to s. 48(1) of the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act 1935.

precedents.case_name: Bihta Cooperative Development Cane Marketing Union Ltd v Bank of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Explanation can widen scope of main section if language shows
precedents.cited_holding: effect must be given to legislative intent even if named Explanation

precedents.citation: J. K. Jute Mills case supra

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with a similar contention Venkatarama Ayyar J. speaking for the Court in J. K. Jute Mills case supra observed at p. 435 The object of the legislation as stated in the long title and in the preamble to the Act was to validate the impugned notification in relation to the amended section.

precedents.case_name: JK Jute Mills Co Ltd v State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: construction avoiding failure of legislative intent to validate should be adopted
precedents.cited_holding: legislature did not fail to validate notification

precedents.citation: Pt. Banarsi Das Bhanot and Ors. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh and Ors.

anchor.surface_text: In Pt. Banarsi Das Bhanot and Ors. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh and Ors. 1 the question arose whether it was permissible for the legislature to empower the executive to amend the Schedule relating to exemptions. This Court by majority answered that question in the affirmative.

precedents.case_name: Pt Banarsi Das Bhanot v State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: permissible to delegate power to executive to amend exemption schedule

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that subject to constitutional restrictions a power to legislate includes a power to legislate prospectively as well as retrospectively. In this regard legislative power to impose tax also includes within itself the power to tax retrospectively--see The Union of India v. Madan Gopal Kabra 1  M. P. Sundararamier Co. v. The State of Andhra Pradesh and Anr.  2  J. K. Jute Mills Co. Ltd. v. The State of Uttar Pradesh and Anr.

anchor.surface_text: there is no justification for the contention that the legislature has usurped any judicial power. The legislature has not purported either directly or by necessary implication to overrule the decisions of the Allahabad High. Court in Tilok Chand Prasan Kumars case  supra . On the other hand it. has accepted that decision as correct but has sought to remove the basis of that decision by retrospectively changing the law.
The High Court rejected these contentions and dismissed the writ petitions. Thereafter these appeals have been brought after obtaining certificates from the High Court.
